Define the sequence given by \(a_1 = \sqrt{2}\) and \(a_{n+1} = (\sqrt{2})^{a_n}\).
Evaluate the first few terms of the sequence to understand its behavior.
Explore whether the sequence converges, diverges, or oscillates.
If the sequence appears to converge, hypothesize the limit \(L\) such that \(L = (\sqrt{2})^L\).
Solve the equation \(L = (\sqrt{2})^L\) for \(L\).
Examine the stability of the sequence at the hypothesized limit \(L\).
Confirm the limit by showing that \( \lim_{n \to \infty} a_{n+1} = \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \) if and only if \(a_n\) approaches \(L\).
